ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Liguria Foods (CTI Foods) recognizes the facility's responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  Liguria Foods is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program.  This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment at Liguria Foods. 



It is Liguria Foods' policy to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the company's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established safety programs that enable plant personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare plant personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.



The Liguria Foods facility draws from decades of internal experience and expertise, as well as resources of our parent company, CTI Foods, to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.



One of the activities associated with the plant's safety program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).  The Corporate PSM Environmental Manager and the EHS Manager are responsible for implementation of the PSM and RMP policies aimed at reducing the risks associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



Liguria Foods processes, packages, and distributes meat products and uses the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system for cold storage, plant cooling, and product freezers.  The maximum intended inventory of ammonia at the facility is approximately 24,000 pounds.



The accidental release prevention program starts with good operating and manufacturing practices.  All ammonia process equipment, piping, and valves are inspected on a regular schedule in accordance with manufacturer and industry recommendations.



For example, all compressors are routinely inspected for oil leaks, pressure and temperature gauge calibrations, vibration analysis, oil pressure, and amp reading for motors;  alignment of compressor motors and bearings, filter changes, vibration readings and sensor calibrations are performed every 6 months;  the condensers are inspected weekly (this includes checking and cleaning nozzles and strainers), motors are greased, fans are checked for cracks, and piping is inspected for leaks;  low and intermediate pressure receiver oil pots are drained, pump pressures are recorded and pumps and valves are defrosted for excessive ice build-up;  visual inspection for equipment and vessel operating limit conditions, piping and valves are assessed for leaks, integrity, and other potential abnormalities on daily basis;  pressure relief valves are replaced on a five year frequency.  Ammonia leak detectors are calibrated semi-annually and trigger local audible and visual alarms for plant operators.  Machinery room ventilation systems operate continuously and are designed for exhaust rates which exceed the emergency exhaust requirements.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies and programs have been developed to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequences of a significant re

lease, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.



Programs developed for the PSM/RMP programs include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, pre-startup safety review, standard operating procedures, training, management of change, mechanical integrity, hot work permit, contractor management, and incident investigation.  To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsible parties at the plant for each element of the facility's PSM / RMP program.  Compliance Audits are also conducted every 3 years that can identify potential compliance issues and recommend actions to achieve full compliance.



In the event of an ammonia release, the emergency response plan is coordinated with the local emergency planning commission (LEPC), the City Fire Department, and the City Emergency Management Department.  The ultimate goal for Liguria Foods' PSM/RMP plan is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid physical damage to the environment.  These programs enable our facility to operate a refrigeration system safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern our network of ammonia refrigeration facilities, as well as the ammonia refrigeration industry.



The Liguria Foods ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  The Liguria Foods facility, including the ammonia system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically outline requirements for the design and operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.  Safety features include ammonia leak detectors in the machinery room, continuous automated ventilation, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic safety cutouts, ASME certified pressure ve

ssels, and emergency stop controls.  The majority of the ammonia inventory is centrally located inside the machine room.  All pressure-rated vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation to protect the vessel's integrity.



Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately.





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following: 



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 



  - On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

  - Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



An investigation into the facility's accident history revealed that there have been no releases of ammonia over the past five years (January 2016 - January 2021) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in 24 hours, or that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History as specified above.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a release of ammonia.



Continued safety improvement for the ammonia refrigeration system is a top priority for Liguria Foods.  The management plan, internal audits, Process Hazard Analysis studies, as well as our prevention programs are monitored and updated as appropriate to ensure that all elements of our PSM/RMP policy remain accurate and complete.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Liguria Foods facility and is maintained by the EHS Manager.  It is based on OSHA requirements for Emergency Action Plan (29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.119) and HAZWOPER (29 CFR 1910.120).  The Emergency Action Plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document which is maintained by the EHS Manager at the facility.



This program contains procedures detailing how the facility will respond to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies.  This program has been coordinated with the City of Humboldt emergency services including: Humboldt Fire Department, Humboldt Police Department, and Humboldt Emergency Management Department.



The facility's Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:



- Key Plant Personnel and Responsibilities

- Outside Agency Notification Contact Information

- Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments

- First Aid Procedures

- Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures

- Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas

- Description for Handling Small Ammonia Releases

- Details of Outside Assistance Available 

- Incident Command System

- Initial and Refresher Training





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The facility has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe work environment. Compliance Audits and PHA studies have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies.



Corporate CTI Foods representatives also provide guidance and assistance for the facility personnel to ensure outstanding issues are resolved and that the facility remains in compliance.  Liguria Foods also plans to improve safety as follows:

 

- Continued involvement of refrigeration and safety personn

el in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies.

- Participation of key personnel in industry recommended training from organizations to ensure the facility is aware of evolving industry standards and techniques used to encourage a safety culture at the facility.

- Conducting routine RMP and PSM meetings to ensure any issues identified by refrigeration personnel, contractors, consultants, or the EHS department are discussed and addressed.

- Reviewing and auditing the risk management and prevention policies to ensure they are maximizing the facility's efforts at limiting the risks associated with handling anhydrous ammonia.
